tn.text: Paul then greets many of the believers in Rome by name.
"I want you to respect Phoebe"
This is a woman's name. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
The word "our" refers to Paul and all believers. AT: "our sister in Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
This was a seaport city in Greece. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
Paul encourages the Roman believers to welcome Phoebe as a fellow believer. AT: "welcome her because we all belong to the Lord" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: in a manner worthy of the believers
tn.text: "in the way that believers should welcome other believers"
Paul encourages the Roman believers to give to Phoebe anything she needs. AT: "and help her by giving her whatever she needs" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: has become a helper of many, and of myself as well
tn.text: "has helped many people, and she has also helped me"
Priscilla was the wife of Aquila. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: my fellow workers in Christ Jesus
tn.text: Paul's "fellow workers" are people who also tell others about Jesus. AT: "who work with me to tell people about Christ Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Greet the church that is in their house
tn.text: "Greet the believers who meet in their house to worship"
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
Paul speaks of Epaenetus as if he were a fruit that he harvested. AT: "first person in Asia to believe in Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is a woman's name. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
These are men's names. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
This could be either 1) Junia, a woman's name, or, much less likely, 2) Junias, a man's name. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

tn.ref: They are prominent among the apostles
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "The apostles know them very well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"my dear friend and fellow believer"

tn.ref: Urbanus ... Stachys ... Apelles ... Aristobulus ... Herodion ... Narcissus
tn.text: These are the names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The word "approved" refers to someone who has been tested and proved to be genuine. AT: "whom Christ has approved"
This refers to those who trust in Jesus. AT: "who are believers" or "who belong to the Lord" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
These are women's names. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

tn.ref: Rufus ... Asyncritus ... Phlegon ... Hermes ... Patrobas ... Hermas
tn.text: These are men's names. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
You can translate this in an active form. AT: "whom the Lord has chosen" because of special qualities (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Paul speaks of the mother of Rufus as if she were his own mother. AT: "his mother, whom I also think of as my mother" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here this means fellow Christians, including both men and women.
These are men's names. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
The name of a woman. Julia was probably the wife of Philologus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
an expression of affection for fellow believers

tn.ref: All the churches of Christ greet you
tn.text: Here Paul speaks in a general manner concerning the churches of Christ. AT: "The believers in all the churches in this area send their greetings to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
Paul gives one last warning to the believers about unity and living for God.
Here this means fellow Christians, including both men and women.
"to watch out for"

tn.ref: who are causing the divisions and stumbling
tn.text: This refers to those who argue and cause others to stop trusting in Jesus. AT: "who are causing believers to argue with one another and to stop having faith in God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: They are going beyond the teaching that you have learned
tn.text: "They teach things that do not agree with the truth you have already learned"
"Stay away from them"

Here "stomach" is a metonym that refers to physical desires. Serving there stomach represents satisfying their desires. AT: "but they only want to satisfy their own selfish desires" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] )

tn.ref: By their smooth and flattering speech
tn.text: The words "smooth" and "flattering" mean basically the same thing. Paul is emphasizing how these people are deceiving believers. AT: "By saying things that seem to be good and true" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This refers to those who are simple, inexperienced, and naive. AT: "those who innocently trust them" or "those who do not know these teachers are fooling them"

tn.ref: For your example of obedience reaches everyone
tn.text: Here Paul speaks of the Roman believers' obedience as if it were a person who could go to people. AT: "For everyone has heard how you obey Jesus" (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: The God of peace will soon crush Satan under your feet
tn.text: The phrase "crush under your feet" refers to complete victory over an enemy. Here Paul speaks of the victory over Satan as if the Roman believers were trampling an enemy under their feet. AT: "Soon God will give you peace and complete victory over Satan" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: innocent to that which is evil
tn.text: "not involved in doing evil things"
Paul gives greetings from the believers who are with him.
These are men's names. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Tertius, who write this epistle down
tn.text: Tertius is the man who wrote down what Paul spoke. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"greet you as a fellow believer"
These are men's names. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This refers to Gaius, the person in whose house Paul and his fellow believers gathered for worship.
This is a person who takes care of the money for a group.

tn.ref: May the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all
tn.text: Here the word "grace" refers to the Lord's blessings upon his people. AT: "May the Lord Jesus Christ continue to act kindly toward you all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Paul closes with a prayer of blessing.
Here the word "now" marks the closing section of the letter. If you have a way of doing this in your language, you can use it here.
Paul speaks here of having strong faith as if a person were standing, instead of falling. AT: "to make your faith strong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: according to my gospel and the preaching of Jesus Christ
tn.text: "by the good news that I have preached about Jesus Christ"

tn.ref: according to the revelation of the mystery that has been kept secret from long ago
tn.text: Paul says that God has revealed previously hidden truths to the believers. He speaks of these truths as if they were a secret. You can translate this in an active form. AT: "because God has revealed to us believers the secret that he was keeping for a long time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: but that now has been revealed and made known by the prophetic scriptures according to the command of the eternal God
tn.text: The verbs "revealed" and "made known" mean basically the same thing. Paul uses both of them to emphasize his point. You can combine these words and translate this in an active form. AT: "but now the eternal God has made it known through the scriptures" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: for the obedience of faith among all the Gentiles
tn.text: Here "obedience" and "faith" are abstract nouns. You can use the verbs "obey" and "trust" in your translation. AT: "so that all nations will obey God because they trust in him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Paul continues his closing statement. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:rom:16:25|16:25]])

tn.ref: to the only wise God ... be the glory forever. Amen
tn.text: Here "through Jesus Christ" refers to what Jesus did. To give "glory" means to praise God. AT: "Because of what Jesus Christ has done for us, we will praise forever the one who alone is God and who alone is wise. Amen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
